rsbNotes.title: Jer 46–51
rsbNotes.text: 46:1–51:64 This section of Jeremiah comprises a series of judgment oracles against the surrounding nations.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48
rsbNotes.text: 48:1–47 This chapter records the oracle against Moab; cf. Is. 15; 16; Ezek. 25:8–11; Amos 2:1–3. Moab was an enemy of Israel (Judg. 3:12–14; 2 Kin. 3:4–27). It was an ally of Judah against Babylon (27:3), but supplied troops for Nebuchadnezzar against Jehoiakim (2 Kin. 24:2). Its defeat by Nebuchadnezzar may have come in 582 b.c. following a rebellion.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:1
rsbNotes.text: 48:1 Nebo . . . Kiriathaim. Originally these towns were allocated to the tribe of Reuben (Num. 32:3, 37, 38; Josh. 13:15, 19).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:2
rsbNotes.text: 48:2 Heshbon. This village was also assigned to Reuben (Num. 32:37; Josh. 13:17).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:7
rsbNotes.text: 48:7 Chemosh. A god of Moab worshiped by Solomon (1 Kin. 11:7, 33; 2 Kin. 23:13). Images of defeated gods were often carried off into exile.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:8
rsbNotes.text: 48:8 The destroyer. Probably Nebuchadnezzar.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:11–12
rsbNotes.text: 48:11, 12 The wine left to age represents Moab’s complacency. Their ease and security will vanish as quickly as a bottle empties when overturned.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:13
rsbNotes.text: 48:13 Bethel. Possibly a reference to the name El Bethel used for the Lord in Jeroboam’s apostate worship at Bethel (1 Kin. 12:28–30). That cult had not prevented the Assyrians from plundering the land in 722 b.c. (2 Kin. 18:9–12).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:19
rsbNotes.text: 48:19 Aroer. Southeast of Dibon, this border fortress on the Arnon River (v. 20) is here pictured anxiously watching the flight of the refugees.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:20
rsbNotes.text: 48:20 Arnon. That is, in the region along the Arnon. It was the most important river in Moab.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:28
rsbNotes.text: 48:28 dwell in the rock. See Is. 2:10.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:32
rsbNotes.text: 48:32 Sibmah . . . Sea of Jazer. See Is. 16:8.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:38
rsbNotes.text: 48:38 housetops of Moab. It was customary to offer incense upon rooftops as an act of worship (2 Kin. 23:12).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:40
rsbNotes.text: 48:40 eagle. This would be Nebuchadnezzar (Ezek. 17:3).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 48:45–46
rsbNotes.text:
48:45, 46 Derived from Num. 21:28, 29, but Jeremiah redirects Balaam’s prophecy against the Amorites by applying it to Moab.

Sihon. He was an Amorite ruler in Moses’ time, with his capital at Heshbon (Num. 21:21–30).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:1–6
rsbNotes.text: 49:1–6 A prophecy against the Ammonites. See Ezek. 25:1–7; Amos 1:13–15. Ammon, an old enemy of Israel (Judg. 11:4–33; 1 Sam. 11:1–11; 2 Sam. 10; 1 Kin. 4:13–19), was located in Trans-Jordan just north of Moab. Like Moab, it was part of an alliance against Babylon (27:3), and like Moab it supplied troops to Nebuchadnezzar against Judah (2 Kin. 24:2). Its hostility to Gedaliah (40:13–41:3) suggests a rebellion against Babylon, probably leading to an attack that virtually ended its existence as an autonomous nation.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:1
rsbNotes.text: 49:1 Milcom. The chief god of the Ammonites (32:35 note; 1 Kin. 11:5).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:2
rsbNotes.text: 49:2 Rabbah. This city is identified with modern Amman in Jordan.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:3
rsbNotes.text:
49:3 Heshbon. As a border town, it may have belonged to Ammon at some time also (Judg. 11:26).

Ai. Not the city of Ai familiar from the events of Josh. 8. Its location is not known.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:7–22
rsbNotes.text: 49:7–22 A prophecy against Edom. See also 27:3; Is. 21:11, 12; Ezek. 25:12–14; Amos 1:11, 12; Obad. 1–16. Edom was an old enemy of Israel (2 Sam. 8:13, 14) and had caused special bitterness by assisting Babylon against Judah.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:7
rsbNotes.text: 49:7 Teman. A region of Edom representing the whole.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:8
rsbNotes.text: 49:8 Esau. The brother of Jacob, whose name was another designation for Edom (Gen. 25:29, 30). See also Obad. 10.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:13
rsbNotes.text: 49:13 Bozrah. The capital of Edom.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 49:22
rsbNotes.text: 49:22 eagle. Probably Nebuchadnezzar (as 48:40), though the Edomites were also conquered decisively by Arabs during the sixth century b.c.
